children.value: Cloudflare Logpush supports pushing logs directly to Splunk via the Cloudflare dashboard or via API.
Enable Logpush to Splunk via the dashboard.
To enable the Cloudflare Logpush service:
Log in to the Cloudflare dashboard.
Select the Enterprise domain you want to use with Logpush.
. A modal window opens where you will need to complete several steps.
Select the dataset you want to push to a storage service.
Select the data fields to include in your logs. Add or remove fields later by modifying your settings in
Enter or select the following destination information:
Splunk raw HTTP Event Collector URL
Once connected, Cloudflare lists Splunk as a connected service under
. Edit or remove connected services from here.
To set up a Splunk Logpush job:
Create a job with the appropriate endpoint URL and authentication parameters.
Enable the job to begin pushing logs.
Unlike configuring Logpush jobs for AWS S3, GCS, or Azure, there is no ownership challenge when configuring Logpush to Splunk.
To create a job, make a
request to the Logpush jobs endpoint with the following fields:
(optional) - Use your domain name as the job name.
- A log destination consisting of an endpoint URL, channel id, insecure-skip-verify flag, source type, authorization header in the string format below.
: The Splunk raw HTTP Event Collector URL with port. For example:
Cloudflare expects the HEC network port to be configured to
Cloudflare expects the Splunk endpoint to be
while configuring and setting up the Logpush job.
Ensure you have enabled HEC in Splunk. Refer to
for information on how to set up HEC in Splunk.
: A unique channel ID. This is a random GUID that you can generate by:
Using an online tool like the
Using the command line.  For example:
: Boolean value. Cloudflare recommends setting this value to
as shown in Splunk examples and is
recommended. Only set this value to
when HEC uses a self-signed certificate.
Cloudflare highly recommends setting this value to false. Refer to the Logpush FAQ for more information.
: The Splunk source type. For example:
: The Splunk authorization token that is URL-encoded. For example:
- The category of logs you want to receive. Refer to
for the full list of supported datasets.
(optional) - To configure fields, sample rate, and timestamp format, refer to
To enable a  job, make a
request to the Logpush jobs endpoint. Use the job ID returned from the previous step in the URL and send
3. Create WAF rule for Splunk HEC endpoint (optional)

If you have the Cloudflare Web Application Firewall (WAF) turned on, you may see a CAPTCHA challenge when Cloudflare makes a request to Splunk HTTP Event Collector (HEC). To make sure this does not happen, you have to create a WAF rule that allows Cloudflare to bypass the HEC endpoint.
and select your account. Go to the
and enter a descriptive name for it (for example, Splunk).
dropdowns to create a rule. After finishing each row, click
to create the next row of rules. Refer to the table below for the values you should input:
Your Splunk endpoint hostname. For example:
After inputting the values as shown in the table, you should have an Expression Preview with the values you added for your specific rule. The example below reflects the hostname

(http.request.method eq "POST" and http.host eq "splunk.cf-analytics.com" and http.request.uri.path eq "/services/collector/raw" and http.request.uri.query contains "channel" and ip.geoip.asnum eq 132892 and http.user_agent eq "Go-http-client/2.0")
The WAF should now ignore requests made to Splunk HEC by Cloudflare.
